title-group.article-title: The Impact of Short Selling on the Price‐Volume Relationship: Evidence from Hong Kong*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This paper considers the relationship between traded volume and volatility allowing for the impact of short sales. The evidence supports a nonlinear, bidirectional relationship between volume and volatility. Short selling is found to have a significant impact on this relationship, and our results suggest (i) that the Hong Kong market displays greater volatility following a period of short selling and (ii) that asymmetric responses to positive and negative innovations to returns appear to be exacerbated by short selling.

fn.p: Initial drafts of this paper were written while the first author was visiting the Institute of Monetary Research at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. We are grateful to Stefan Gerlach, Matthew Yiu, and all the staff at the HKIMR for their hospitality. Thanks are also due to Boris Hofmann for his comments. We are grateful to the Australian Research Council for financial support under Discovery Grant no. DP0451719. Any remaining errors or omissions are the responsibility of the authors. Contact the corresponding author, Michael McKenzie, atmichael.mckenzie@rmit.edu.au.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is a well‐documented positive relationship between stock return volatility and contemporaneous trading volume (see Karpoff [1987, 113] for a summary). More recent research on this issue however, suggests that this association may be more complicated than was previously thought. For example, Hiemstra and Jones (1994), Chen, Firth, and Rui (2001), and Ratner and Leal (2001) find significant bidirectional causality between returns and volume. Evidence of a relationship between past returns and volume has been documented that has been attributed to tax effects (Lakonishok and Smidt1989) and the rate at which stocks incorporate information (Chordia and Swaminathan2000). Freund and Webb (1999) considered trading volume on the NASDAQ, New York Stock Exchange, and American Stock Exchange and conclude that the type and quantity of information driving trade is different on the NASDAQ compared to the other two exchanges.

The purpose of this paper is to furnish further evidence as to the nature of the relationship between share price volatility and traded volume. Much of the existing literature (Tauchen and Pitts1983; Lamoureaux and Lastrapes1990; Gallant, Rossi, and Tauchen1993), inter alia, assumes that the volume–price change relationship is monotonic and linear. Where nonlinearity is parameterized, the literature has tended to impose symmetry and/or constant correlation on the conditional variance‐covariance structure. Such linearity and/or symmetry assumptions may be tenuous and conceivably lead to model misspecification and ultimately result in unreliable inference. The model specification adopted in our paper is unique in that we test for and, where appropriate, incorporate potential sources of nonlinearity and asymmetry into the modeling process.

One source of the asymmetry discussed in the literature is motivated by the observation that negative shocks elicit a greater response in volatility than positive shocks of an equal magnitude (see, e.g., Black1976; Christie1982; Nelson1991; Campbell and Hentschel1992; Engle and Ng1993; Glosten, Jagannathan, and Runkle1993; Bekaert and Wu2000). In this paper, it is argued that a second form of asymmetry exists that the previous literature has failed to take into account. This asymmetry arises from the activities of traders in the market engaged in short selling. An informed trader will take a short position in the equity of a firm on the basis of unfavorable prospects regarding the company’s future (Diamond and Verrecchia1987). This is distinct from the sales undertaken by traders whose motives are exogenously determined by such factors as portfolio rebalancing, the need for liquidity, and so on. The trading activity of short sellers may, therefore, provide important information as to the amount and type of news available for a given company. Specifically, short sales signify bad news (see Senchack and Starks1993; Choie and Hwang1994; Asquith and Meulbroek1996; Aitken et al.1998), which the literature has found causes markets to overreact compared to good news (see Kaminsky and Schmukler1999; Veronesi1999). In addition to return volatility asymmetry, we hypothesize that the relationship between volume and volatility displays asymmetry in that market responses to a given level of traded volume will differ depending on whether or not short sellers are active in the market on that day.1This hypothesis is previously untested in the literature, and evidence of a short‐sales asymmetry has important implications for model specification, inference, and forecasting.

In this paper, these propositions relating to the presence of nonlinearities and asymmetry in the volume‐volatility relationship are tested using data sampled from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE) that include short‐sales information. Uniquely, this information makes it possible to identify the activities of short sellers on a daily basis. Comparable data are not readily available for other developed markets such as the United States and United Kingdom.

The HKSE is an order‐driven market with continuous trading during opening hours. Short selling was first introduced to the exchange in January 1994, under a pilot program that designated 17 eligible stocks. Under the new rules, investors were able to sell short provided that they have an exercisable and unconditional right to vest the stock and the trade was not to be made at a price below the best current ask price (the “tick rule”).2In March 1996, the tick rule was abandoned in favor of “naked” short selling, and the list of eligible stocks was expanded. In August 1998, the Hong Kong government spent US$12.5 billion buying stocks and futures to support a market that was perceived to be laboring under heavy speculative selling pressure arising from the 1997 Asian crisis. To curb future short selling and prevent a repeat of previous events, a host of new rules were introduced in September 1998, including the reinstatement of the tick rule, albeit in a modified form in which an exemption was made for short‐sales transactions undertaken by stock options market makers in the course of performing their duty.

The broker identifies short‐selling transactions to the exchange at the time of placing the order in the Automatic Order Matching and Execution System. As such, detailed short sales records are kept for trades made on the HKSE, and the exchange makes this information available in the form of a daily report. This report summarizes total daily short‐sales volume and short‐sales value for each individual stock and is usually made available after a 24‐hour delay.

The remainder of this paper proceeds as follows.Section IIdefines some important concepts and details the hypotheses to be tested.Section IIIformally describes the data and, on the basis of the identified properties, outlines an appropriately specified model. The estimation results and the results of various hypothesis tests are presented and discussed inSection IV. Finally,Section Vprovides a brief summary and some concluding comments.

fn.p: An asymmetry in the volume response to different price changes has been found in the literature (see Epps1975; Jennings, Starks, and Fellingham1981; Karpoff1987,1988; Chamberlain, Cheung, and Kwan1991; Assogbavi, Khouri, and Yourougou1995; Kocagil and Shachmurove1998), which has been attributed to heterogeneous expectations (Epps1975; Copeland1976) and the costs of short selling (Karpoff1988). The asymmetry introduced in this paper is different to the extent that it is short sales that proxy news and so drive volatility. This causality is consistent with the theoretical models of the volume‐volatility relationship (see, e.g., Blume, Easley, and O'Hara [1994] and Suominen [2001], who show that volume contains information about fundamental values).
The short‐selling rules on the HKSE are less restrictive than those in the United States (see Asquith and Meulbroek [1996] for a summary).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Traded Volume‐Price Volatility Relationship Hypothesis Tests
sec.p: A common theme in the literature is that “it takes volume to make prices move.” Campbell, Grossman, and Wang (1993), Blume et al. (1994), He and Wang (1995), Chordia and Swaminathan (2000), and Suominen (2001), among others, all predict causal relations from volume to volatility. Motivated by this literature, the first hypothesis to be tested in this paper is that of no Granger causality from volume to prices, as follows.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{1}_{0}$ \end{document} : Volume innovations do not cause price movements.

It is possible, however, that a feedback loop may exist, in which case price movements might cause further volume (see e.g., Hiemstra and Jones1994; Chen et al.2001) Thus the second hypothesis to be tested is of no reverse causality from prices to volume.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{2}_{0}$ \end{document} : Price innovations do not cause movements in volume.

Suominen (2001) introduced a model in which private information about equity returns is available in any given period with some probability that changes stochastically over time. Traders estimate the availability of private information using lagged volume and, as such, modify their trading strategies as the probability of private information entering the market increases. The trades of informed traders (volume), therefore, reveal private information that affects prices (volatility), and hence, a positive relationship is derived. Suominen uses his model to derive a number of propositions relating to the dynamic relationship between volume and return, many of which are testable in the current context.

The Suominen model implies that the covariance between current and past return variances is positive. This provides a theoretical justification for the volatility clustering often observed in time series of asset price innovations. As such, our third hypothesis is as follows.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{3}_{0}$ \end{document} : Price movements do not display autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (ARCH) effects.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{4}_{0}$ \end{document} : Mean reversion occurs in the conditional variance of returns.

Under the Suominen model, when private information has been revealed about asset returns, the order flows of informed investors reflect this information. In this situation, price innovations will no longer be sufficient statistics for predicting changes in the conditional variance. Information on volume will also be necessary to forecast the conditional variance of returns. When the probability of private information arrival is zero, the transition equation for the conditional variance for returns in Suominen's model becomes very similar to a generalized ARCH (GARCH) model. Motivated by this, we test the following hypothesis.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{5}_{0}$ \end{document} : Volume innovations do not cause movements in price volatility.

Essentially, Suominen (2001) predicts one‐way nonlinear causality from volume to price volatility. It is, however, not unlikely that changes in returns volatility themselves may lead to further volume innovations. In this case, one would observe a reverse nonlinear causal relationship in which news about returns innovations contains information that is useful in forecasting the volatility of volume. Thus we test the following hypothesis.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{6}_{0}$ \end{document} : Price innovations do not cause movements in volume volatility.

Karpoff (1987) suggests that the price‐volume relationship may be asymmetric and that the source of this asymmetry can be attributed to the higher costs associated with short sales. The remaining hypotheses to be tested distinguish between asymmetry due to short selling and other forms of asymmetry found in the literature on modeling equity volatility

A common finding in the literature on stock market volatility is that negative shocks cause more volatility than positive shocks of equal magnitude. One potential explanation for such asymmetry in variance is the so‐called leverage effect of Black (1976) and Christie (1982). In brief, this theory proposes that as equity values fall, the weight attached to debt in a firm’s capital structure rises, ceteris paribus. This induces equity holders, who bear the residual risk of the firm, to perceive the stream of future income accruing to their portfolios as being relatively more risky. An alternative view of the dynamics by which this asymmetry may work is provided by the “volatility‐feedback” hypothesis of Campbell and Hentschel (1992). With constant dividends, if expected returns increase when stock return volatility increases, then stock prices should fall following a rise in volatility. Bekaert and Wu (2000) reject the pure leverage effect in favor of volatility feedback as an explanation for asymmetric volatility in a sample of Nikkei 225 stocks. Nelson (1991), Engle and Ng (1993), and Glosten et al. (1993), among others, use univariate ARCH models to document asymmetry in equity volatility. Brooks, Henry, and Persand (2002) use a multivariate asymmetric GARCH approach to model and price this type of asymmetry.

Following Kroner and Ng (1998) and Bekaert and Wu (2000), we may define asymmetric volatility as
In other words, as a result of negative unanticipated returns, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\varepsilon _{i,r,t}< 0$ \end{document} , the expectation of conditional volatility of return is revised upward. On the other hand, the downward revision of volatility in response to a positive unanticipated return innovation is relatively smaller. Kroner and Ng (1998) refer to such effects as “own‐variance asymmetry.” The seventh hypothesis to be tested in this paper is as follows.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{7}_{0}$ \end{document} : No own‐variance asymmetry occurs in returns.

Motivated by this literature, we may define own‐variance and cross‐variance asymmetry. With \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\varepsilon _{i,V,t}$ \end{document} defined as an innovation to volume, own‐variance asymmetry in volume occurs if
The eighth hypothesis may be specified as follows.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{8}_{0}$ \end{document} : No own‐variance asymmetry occurs in volume.
Cross‐variance asymmetry is said to occur between volume and volatility if

For volume to display cross‐variance asymmetry, it must be the case that
Definitions(3)and(4)give rise to the following hypotheses.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{9}_{0}$ \end{document} : No cross‐variance asymmetry occurs in return.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{10}_{0}$ \end{document} : No cross‐variance asymmetry occurs in volume.

Similarly, covariance asymmetry occurs if, following a negative unanticipated return (or volume) innovation, the revision to the expectation of the conditional covariance differs from that following a positive unanticipated return (or volume) innovation of equal magnitude. Formally, covariance asymmetry occurs if
Definition(5)leads to the following hypothesis.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{11}_{0}$ \end{document} : No covariance asymmetry occurs in the returns‐volume relationship.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{12}_{0}$ \end{document} : No short‐sales asymmetry occurs in return.

\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $H^{13}_{0}$ \end{document} : No short‐sales asymmetry occurs in volume.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Data Description
sec.p: To avoid problems associated with thin trading and illiquidity, the stocks analyzed in this paper consist of the current constituents of the Hang Seng index. Over the period 1994–2001, these 21 stocks were among the most actively traded and liquid stocks on the HKSE, collectively representing approximately 53% of daily market turnover and 74% of total market capitalization. (source: Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission, Markets and Industry Statistics [http://www.hksfc.org.hk/eng/statistics/html/index/index1.html], tables B8, B9). We exclude MTR, however, since it is a recently listed company and, as such, does not provide enough data for analysis. Of these 21 companies, 14 were included in the 1994 pilot short‐selling program. Although daily short‐sales information is available for a wider range of companies, illiquidity becomes an issue when analyzing these lower‐capitalization stocks. To conserve space, this paper reports results only for Cathay Pacific (Cathay), Cheung Kong, Hong Kong and China Gas (HK&C Gas), HSBC Holdings (HSBC), Henderson Investment (Henderson), and Hutchison Telecom (Hutchison). The unreported results for the remaining 15 companies are qualitatively consistent with those presented and are available on request from the authors.

Table 1presents some summary statistics for the returns (panel A), traded volume (panel B), and short‐sales volume (panel C) for each of the six companies. The average return for four of the six companies is positive; the lowest mean return is −0.03% for Cathay, and the highest mean return is 0.05% for HSBC. In general, Hong Kong stock prices exhibit a great deal of variation, with one‐day returns in excess of 20% common across the sample. Henderson experienced the largest one‐day fall of 19% on October 28, 1997, when the price fell from $6.20 to $5.10. The standard deviation for these returns data is greater than that generated by the market index. Not surprisingly, given these large price movements, the Jarque‐Bera test for normality is rejected in each instance. HSBC is the most heavily traded stock in our sample and also exhibits the greatest level of short interest. Short sales are observed 85.85% of the time, with an average daily short‐sold volume of 397,862 shares. Henderson exhibits the lowest volume of short sales: on average, 95,550 shares are sold short each day, and short selling occurs only 36.14% of the time. Table 1

The returns series were calculated as \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $r_{i,t}=100\times \mathrm{ln}\,( P_{i,t\,}/ P_{i,t-1}) $ \end{document} , where prices are measured in HK$. The volume series and short‐sales series are measured in number of shares traded per day.
*
As short selling commenced for Henderson in June 1996, the sample period for the short sale summary statistics was estimated over a restricted sample period. The exclusion of these two years does not significantly alter these statistics as only a relatively small amount of short trading took place in this initial period.

The test is performed as \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $T\cdot R^{2}$ \end{document} from estimation of(9)for \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $y_{i,t}=\tilde{r}_{i,t},\,\tilde{v}_{i,t}$ \end{document} , whereTrepresents the sample size. A similar test for dependence in the conditional second moment of the data may be performed using a Ljung‐Box test on the squared residuals. The first two rows of panels A and B intable 2present the results of LM and Ljung‐Box tests for up to fifth‐order ARCH applied to the returns and volume data. In all cases the null of no ARCH was rejected at all usual levels of confidence for the returns data. For the changes in volume data, the null of no ARCH is rejected for all series except Cathay, whose results are marginal, and for HK&C Gas, where the data fail to reject the null of no fifth‐order ARCH. In both these cases, however, there is strong evidence of first‐order ARCH. Table 2
Time‐Series Properties of the Adjusted Data

Note.—Day‐of‐week effects, vesting rule changes, and government intervention effects have been removed. The sample period is January 30, 1994, to September 5, 2001. ARCH(5) is the Engle (1982) LM test for up to fifth‐order ARCH.Q 2(5) is a Ljung‐Box test on the squared data. Negative sign, negative size, positive size, and joint test are Engle‐Ng (1993) LM tests for asymmetry in variance. Short sales is an LM test for variance asymmetry as described ineq. (13). Marginal significance levels are displayed in brackets.
Finally, the Engle and Ng (1993) joint test for asymmetry in variance is based on the regression

Significance of the parameter φ1indicates the presence ofsign bias. That is, positive and negative realizations of ε t affect future volatility differently than the prediction of the model. Similarly significance of φ2or φ3would suggestsize bias, where not only the sign but also the magnitude of the innovation is important. A joint test for sign and size bias, based on the LM principle, may be performed as \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $T\cdot R^{2}$ \end{document} from the estimation of(12). The results intable 2suggest significant evidence of negative size bias in the returns data that is consistent with the presence of a leverage effect. There is less evidence of asymmetry, however, in the change in volume data.

Panels A and B oftable 2also present the results from a test for bias in the conditional variance arising from the failure to adequately capture the effects of short selling. Again this test may be performed using an LM approach based on the auxiliary regression
where \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $SS_{t}=1$ \end{document} if short selling occurred on daytand zero otherwise. The results of this procedure provide strong evidence of short‐sales asymmetry in the returns and volume data, implying that volatility tends to be higher following a period of short selling.

Optimal inference about the conditional relationship between volume and volatility requires that the model be correctly specified. These new results on the presence of a short‐sales asymmetry in equity volatility have important implications. A failure to control for this asymmetry would represent a misspecification of the conditional characterization of the data and is likely to yield misleading inference and forecasts.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Model Specification
sec.p: The data description suggests that the filtered returns display significant evidence of (i) ARCH, (ii) negative size bias, and (iii) bias to short‐sales activity. The filtered volume data display strong evidence of ARCH and bias to short‐sales activity and weaker evidence of size bias.

It is important to note that(14)implies that only the magnitude and not the sign of innovations is important in determining current time‐varying variances and covariances. This assumption of symmetric conditional variance‐covariance matrices must be considered tenuous given the results presented intable 2and the existing body of evidence documenting the asymmetric response of equity volatility to positive and negative innovations of equal magnitude (see, e.g., Engle and Ng1993; Glosten et al.1993; Kroner and Ng1998; Brooks et al.2002).

To allow for an asymmetric response to short‐sales behavior, we use the dummy variable \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $SS_{t}$ \end{document} , which takes the value one if there was short selling on daytand zero otherwise. We may define

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Model Estimates and Diagnostics

fn.p: On the basis ofQ 2(12), though, there is some evidence of twelfth‐order dependence in the squared standardized residuals of the returns equation for Henderson.
The exceptions are HK&C Gas, which violates P‐SVand P‐SRV, and Hutchison, which violates PSV.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Hypothesis Tests
sec.p: The estimated model discussed in subsectionAcan be used to test a number of hypotheses about the relationship between price movements and volume and the effect of short selling on this relationship. A number of hypotheses related to the presence of asymmetries and nonlinearities in the data can also be considered.

Similarly, row b oftable 5reveals that the data fail to reject the null of no reverse causality from prices to volume for all series except HK&C Gas and Cheung Kong. Thus our second hypothesis, that price innovations do not cause movements in volume, receives little support. Taken together, the evidence in the first two rows oftable 5provides minimal evidence of linear causality between returns and volume and vice versa.

Overall, our results suggest that to obtain an adequate conditional characterization of the data, the model must allow for asymmetric response to innovations in returns and to innovations in volume and also allow for the presence of short selling. Any candidate conditional characterization of the data that omitted any of these features would be necessarily misspecified and potentially yield misleading inference and forecasts.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper reconsiders the relationship between traded volume and stock returns using daily data sampled for range of Hong Kong equities. Unlike the previous literature, this paper tests for and, where appropriate, incorporates potential sources of nonlinearity and asymmetry into the modeling process.

Consistent with previous results, this paper provides strong evidence of time variation and asymmetric response to shocks in the variance‐covariance structure of asset returns. This implies that the Hong Kong market will be relatively more volatile when prices are trending downward. In contrast to previous findings, however, this paper documents a new form of asymmetry in the dynamic process that determines stock return volatility. The source of this asymmetry is the trading activity of short sellers. Short sales are motivated by bad news about a company’s future prospects. The trading activity of short sellers (volume) reveals their informational advantage to noise traders and, as markets typically overreact to bad news compared to good news, elicits a larger response in volatility compared to a day in which short sellers are absent from the market. This is not to suggest, however, that volume drives prices as much of the theoretical literature suggests and many empirical studies implicitly assume. Rather, the parameter estimates of our model clearly indicate the presence of a strong nonlinear bidirectional relationship between innovations to volume and returns volatility.

These results suggest that the standard model of trading volume driving the first two conditional moments of returns may be misspecified in the Hong Kong context. Our evidence supports a nonlinear bidirectional relationship between trading volume and price volatility for Hong Kong stocks. Further, a number of important asymmetries exist in this relationship. The data display greater volatility in response to a price fall than to a price rise of equal magnitude. Furthermore, the evidence suggests that the market displays greater volatility following a period of short selling than would otherwise have been the case. Finally, the asymmetric response of returns volatility to positive and negative innovations to returns appears to be exacerbated by short selling.
